Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research : DAT: Fromgrant to commercialization: an integrated demonstration database which permits tracing, assessing, and measuring the impact of scientific funding

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
It has long been received wisdom that investment in science greatly facilitates the technological progress that ultimately improves economic productivity and living standards. Unfortunately, the systematic and quantitative evidence to support these arguments remains thin and expensive to produce. Name ambiguity makes this difficult: different scientists may share the same names, and conversely, the same scientist may have their name listed differently within or across publication and patent databases. As a consequence, the collaborative networks of scientists remain unidentified, and the gatekeepers between science and technology have not been systematically identified.

Intellectual Merit: This project develops a large-scale database that links Medline papers and U.S. patents, through identification of individuals who authored both papers and patents using state-of-the-art name disambiguation algorithms. These patent-paper-author links in turns enable identification of similar organizations and in some cases, science/technology fields and geography. The resulting database is used in three exemplary analyses that aim to: 1) study the impact of grants upon science and technical productivity, 2) identify the gatekeepers between science and technology and study how knowledge flows between these two realms, and 3) understand how collaborative, institutional, organizational, and regional factors influence these processes.

Broader Impact: The resulting database is publicly available. This both enables science policy scholars to develop systematic and convincing evidence for investment recommendations and enables person-centered research of the science-technology interface of numerous other kinds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Innovation in science and technology is driven by scientists and inventors, and the results of their efforts are recorded in bibliographic databases. This project brought together two large-scale disambiguation efforts, one to disambiguate all inventor names in the USPTO patent database and one to disambiguate all author names in the PubMed biomedical articles database, and link the two. Name disambiguation here refers to the process of identifying all the articles and patents written by an individual, and doing this for millions of authors and inventors. This is a major statistical and computational challenge for large bibliographic databases where a name is typically shared by many individuals (a potential for lumping different people together), and many individuals have records with name variants (a potential for splitting a person into multiples). The outcome of this project includes foundational contributions to disambiguation methodology, new tools and datasets, and several findings resulting from exemplary studies using the disambiguated data:

We found that disambiguation across domains (that is, identifying author-inventors across patents and papers) presents new and distinctive challenges. The records differ in some meta-data (USPTO assign patents to technology classes; while the US National Library of Medicine assigns medical subject headings to papers)  and in writing style and vocabulary (because papers are scholarly and patents are legal documents). To overcome these issues, we first created a preliminary disambiguation, and then constructed a dictionary of what we call implicit word-to-word links that are common within, but not across, author-inventors. This permits establishing implicit subject matter links across the records when they do not share any words or meta-data explicitly. We also found that author-inventors are relatively uncommon (i.e., the overlap of authors and inventors is relatively small) and so substantial evidence was required to make proper links, particularly for names that are very common. Out of millions of authors and inventors, only about 200,000 author-inventors were confidently identified. This method fails to capture individuals who wrote papers and patents on very different technologies (e.g., patents on inkjet printing vs. papers on the genetic analysis of cancer) in different locations and with different collaborators. The resulting author-inventor dataset has been made available for download and browsing. A new version of the inventor disambiguation was also produced and analyzed, and made available for download (Li, Lai, D’Amour et al., 2014).

Using the disambiguated data, we found that failure to resolve ambiguity (that is, assuming a name points to one person, and nobody has name variants) completely distorts our global view of collaborative innovation as represented by the statistical properties of large-scale co-author and co-inventor networks For example, lumping artificially and dramatically reduces estimates of clustering (the degree to which individuals tend to form cliques), assortativity (the degree to which individuals tend to collaborate with others like them), and the typical number of hops between any two individuals in the network. Our data also suggest that the so-called “power-law” of collaborator counts in science and technology might be an artifact of name ambiguity, and probably should be refined, for example, to account for the finite the capacity of individuals to form new, substantive collaborations (Fegley and Torvik, 2013). We also developed a new technique for robustly imputing the gender of authors and inventors based on their names, and characterized the gender-disparities over time and across a papers and patents (Smith, Singh, Torvik, 2013). It is well known that collaborative work tend to receive more citations than solo-work, and that collaborative work is the new norm. We identified several aspects of collaborations that help explain this effect (Hurley, Ogier, Torvik, 2013).

  2. Fegley BD, Torvik VI. Has large-scale named entity network analysis been resting on a flawed assumption. PLOS ONE 2013; 8(7): e70299.
  3. Smith BN, Singh M, Torvik VI. A search engine approach to estimating temporal changes in gender orientation of first names. Proceedings of the 13th ACM/IEEE-CS joint conference on Digital libraries, Indianapolis, IN, USA July 22-26, 2013. Pp. 199-208.
  4. Hurley L, Ogier A, Torvik VI. Deconstructing the collaborative impact: article and author characteristics that influence citation count. Proceedings of the 76th ASIST Annual Meeting, Montreal, Canada, Nov. 2013.
